intro: Haplopappus gilmanii, commonly known as Gilman's pappus, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It belongs to the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads and robust, often hairy stems. The plant typically grows in arid or semi-arid environments, showcasing adaptations to drought and poor soil conditions. Its small, yellow flowers are surrounded by a pappus, a structure that aids in wind dispersal of its seeds. Haplopappus gilmanii is often found in rocky or sandy soils, contributing to the ecological diversity of its native habitats.
